channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live George Floyd Memorial Service and Protest Updates
item.description: Once again, thousands of demonstrators poured into the nation’s streets, gathering outside City Hall in Seattle and marching across the Brooklyn Bridge.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crowd lingered after the memorial service for George Floyd in Minneapolis on Thursday.

item.title: Mourners Gather to Remember George Floyd in Minneapolis Memorial
item.description: Political leaders, celebrities, family members and friends gathered for a memorial that was to be followed in coming days by events in Mr. Floyd’s memory in North Carolina and Texas.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Joshua McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners carried the coffin of George Floyd on Thursday to the site of a memorial service in his honor in Minneapolis.

item.title: Live Coronavirus News Updates
item.description: Fine-grained data on race and ethnicity may help the U.S. begin to address inequities. New infections around the world are topping 100,000 a day. An Indian vaccine manufacturer is ready to make a billion doses.
item.media:description: Workers attend to a patient at the emergency room of Lincoln Medical Center in the Bronx.

item.title: Trump, On George Floyd Protests, Tests a Role He’s Long Admired: A Strongman
item.description: The president’s unapologetic calls for force, and his efforts to bring the military into his political line, follow a strongman’s playbook. It’s a risky move for him, and for democracy.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: President Trump brandishing a Bible in front of St. John’s Church in Washington on Monday.

item.title: With Broad Subpoena Power, Republicans Seek to Undercut Russia Inquiry
item.description: Republicans on two Senate committees moved to give their chairmen power to subpoena dozens of Obama administration and F.B.I. officials for the election-year inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:description: “The public can judge whether I am on some cause for Trump or not,” said Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, answering Democrats’ criticism.

item.title: Doctors Heavily Overprescribed Antibiotics Early in the Pandemic
item.description: Now they are using lessons from the experience to urge action on the growing problem of drug-resistant infections before it’s too late.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: A coronavirus patient received care at Elmhurst Hospital in Queens last month.

item.title: Dr. Bertram Brown, Mental Health Advocate, Is Dead at 89
item.description: In the 1960s and ’70s, as head of the National Institute of Mental Health, he was instrumental in improving programs for intellectually disabled Americans.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Dr. Bertram S. Brown, far right, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, addressing the news media in 1972 about his department’s report to Congress on marijuana. The agency recommended decriminalization.

item.title: Senate Confirms Conservative Filmmaker to Lead U.S. Media Agency
item.description: The Senate approved Michael Pack, an ally of Stephen K. Bannon’s, to run the agency in charge of the Voice of America. President Trump hopes he will dictate more favorable news coverage.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: United States Agency for Global Media
item.media:credit: Bill Crandall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Pack in 2006.

item.title: Why Some Democrats Worry About the Whiteness of Biden’s Inner Circle
item.description: Even as his team adds people of color, allies worry that a lack of diverse viewpoints at the top could come with a steep cost: the possibility of taking for granted his strength with black voters.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.category: League of United Latin American Citizens
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: The people setting strategy for former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. still skew heavily white.

item.title: Jake Paul Charged With Misdemeanor Trespassing After Mall Looting
item.description: Videos posted on social media showed the 23-year-old YouTube star at a Scottsdale, Ariz., mall that was being looted on Saturday night.
item.dc:creator: Taylor Lorenz
item.media:credit: Jake Michaels for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Paul at his home in West Hollywood, Calif., in 2017.

item.title: Trump and the Military: A Mutual Embrace Might Dissolve on America’s Streets
item.description: “There is a thin line between the military’s tolerance for questionable partisan moves over the past three years and the point where these become intolerable,” a retired general said.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Members of the National Guard lining the streets near White House during a protest on Wednesday.

item.title: McConnell Protégé Moves Toward Confirmation to D.C. Appeals Court
item.description: The Judiciary Committee cleared Judge Justin Walker for a floor vote over the objections of Democrats, who said he was not qualified.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: Justin Walker, 38, was named a district court judge just last year.

item.title: ‘Like Trash in a Landfill’: Carbon Dioxide Keeps Piling Up in the Atmosphere
item.description: Levels of planet-warming carbon dioxide reached another record in May, the month when they normally peak.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: The Mauna Loa Observatory, NOAA’s atmospheric research facility, in Hawaii.

item.title: Why Aren’t We All Talking About Breonna Taylor?
item.description: Like George Floyd, she was also killed by the police, but her case remains largely disconnected from the broader narrative.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesting the deaths of Breonna Taylor, and others, in Louisville, Ky.

item.title: Murkowski Endorses Mattis Criticism of Trump, Calling it ‘Necessary and Overdue’
item.description: The Alaska Republican suggested the former defense secretary’s scathing remarks might serve as a tipping point, prodding other Republicans to go public with longstanding concerns about President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: “I thought General Mattis’s words were true and honest and necessary and overdue,” said Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska.

item.title: Serving in the Army as a Queer Black Man Opened My Eyes to Racism in America
item.description: I started filming the protests in New York so I could draw attention to the realities of black America that I was first exposed to during my military service.
item.dc:creator: Richard Brookshire and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Videos of the George Floyd Protests
item.description: Video has become the central lens through which Americans have viewed the nationwide unrest that has followed the death of George Floyd. Here’s what we’re seeing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Manhattan after curfew on Wednesday.

item.title: Hutton Gibson, Extremist and Father of Mel Gibson, Dies at 101
item.description: His anti-Semitic, anti-Vatican views gained notoriety after his son directed the controversial film, “The Passion of the Christ.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz

item.title: 2,000 Free Meals a Night, Seasoned by Silicon Valley Chefs
item.description: With unemployment soaring in this region of haves and have-nots, a local Boys and Girls Club has transformed into a pop-up takeout operation to feed the most disadvantaged.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.category: Boys and Girls Clubs of America
item.media:credit: James Tensuan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miles Harris, a volunteer, handed out free dinners at the Boys and Girls Club in East Palo Alto, Calif., last month.

item.title: Iran Frees Navy Veteran Held for Two Years
item.description: The release of Michael R. White, announced by his mother in the United States and tweeted by President Trump, came a day after an Iranian scientist held by the American authorities was returned to Iran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Michael R. White with his mother, Joanne White, in 2018.

item.title: Police Release Personnel Files of Officers Charged in George Floyd’s Death
item.description: Many of the pages, released by the Minneapolis Police Department, were heavily redacted, but they revealed details of the officers’ lives before joining the department and during their time on the force.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Tim Arango, John Eligon and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The memorial where George Floyd died in the custody of the Minneapolis police.

item.title: How Will the Protest Movement Evolve?
item.description: New charges in Minneapolis, but calls for systemic change remain: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump’s Rough Patch
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: 11 Great Alternatives to the Top National Parks
item.description: Whether you like hiking, fishing, volcanoes, trees or even fossilized trees, there is a less-traveled and still awe-inspiring national park for you.
item.dc:creator: Jon Waterman
item.category: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Reserve (Colorado)

item.title: Pandemic Lockdowns Lead to Less Traffic and Better Air
item.description: Fewer cars on the road during the pandemic has meant cleaner air, but not necessarily fewer traffic deaths. Can we have both?
item.dc:creator: Tanya Mohn
item.media:description: Mexico City’s ring road, known as the Periférico, on May 8.

item.title: Workers Fearful of the Coronavirus Are Getting Fired and Losing Their Benefits
item.description: Thousands who refuse to return to work are being reported to the state to have their unemployment benefits potentially revoked.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Lyon lost his unemployment benefits after his former bosses reported him to the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment.

item.title: Witness Who Was in George Floyd’s Car, Maurice Lester Hall, Says His Friend Did Not Resist Arrest
item.description: Maurice Lester Hall, who fled Minneapolis after witnessing George Floyd’s death, was arrested Monday in Houston and interviewed by a Minnesota investigator.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green and Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of George Floyd at the site of his deadly car stop in Minneapolis.

item.title: Another Man Who Said ‘I Can’t Breathe’ Died in Custody. An Autopsy Calls It Homicide.
item.description: Manuel Ellis of Tacoma, Wash., died in part as a result of how he was restrained, according to the medical examiner, who concluded that his death was a homicide.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: A photo of Manuel Ellis, who died in police custody in March, in Tacoma, Wash.

item.title: Ousted Watchdog Says State Dept. Official Pressured Him to End Inquiry Into Pompeo
item.description: Steve A. Linick, the former State Department inspector general, testified that a top agency official tried to “bully” him as he investigated the potential misconduct by the administration.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Steve Linick, an inspector general who was fired from the State Department, told Congress that a friend of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo had “pressured him to act” in ways that he felt were “inappropriate.”

item.title: Senate Gives Final Approval to Revisions to Small-Business Program
item.description: The legislation now heads to the president’s desk, just days before some businesses will run out of time to spend the loan money.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Senate unanimously approved adjustments to the Paycheck Protection Program on Wednesday evening.

item.title: New Charges for Former Minneapolis Police Officers as Protests Persist
item.description: The former officer who held his knee on George Floyd’s neck was charged with second-degree murder. Three other officers now face charges as well.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clifton Traxler-Owens reacted on Wednesday to new criminal charges in the killing of George Floyd. “It’s actually peaceful to understand that somebody heard your voice,” Mr. Traxler-Owens said in Minneapolis.

item.title: Mattis Accuses Trump of Dividing the Nation in a Time of Crisis
item.description: He “does not even pretend to try” to unite Americans, the former defense secretary said, breaking his long public silence on the president amid protests across the nation.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Jim Mattis’s refusal to publicly denounce President Trump since his resignation had earned him criticism.

item.title: Today’s Activism: Spontaneous, Leaderless, but Not Without Aim
item.description: Welcome to 21st-century activism, where social media is the strongest organizer. At the core is an egalitarian spirit, a belief that everyone’s voice matters.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tony Clark, 27, addressed demonstrators on Monday at the site where George Floyd was arrested in Minneapolis shortly before his death.

item.title: Fortress Washington: Authority vs. Liberty
item.description: Like the country it supposedly answers to, Washington has been on edge, hovered over by low-flying helicopters and patrolled by law enforcement agents from a stew of federal agencies.
item.dc:creator: Mark Leibovich
item.category: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives
item.media:description: Protests in Washington on Wednesday near the White House. The city has been on edge, hovered over by low-flying helicopters and patrolled by law enforcement agents from a stew of federal agencies

item.title: Mark Esper Breaks With Trump on Using Troops Against Protestors
item.description: Mark Esper’s comments reflected the turmoil within the military over President Trump, who has said he could put active-duty troops on the streets to perform law enforcement functions.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Maggie Haberman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Mark T. Esper, the defense secretary, on Monday with members of the National Guard near the White House.

item.title: Trump ‘Remains Healthy’ After Taking Hydroxychloroquine, His Doctor Says
item.description: The president has hailed the drug as a cure for Covid-19, but his own health officials have questioned its effectiveness and safety. His doctor’s comments were part of a summary of the president’s health.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Lawrence K. Altman
item.media:description: A summary of President Trump’s health reported that he had gained one pound since last year but had seen a decline in his cholesterol levels.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The pandemic is threatening to derail the careers of an entire generation of working women.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: E.R. Visits Drop Sharply During Pandemic
item.description: People even with heart problems are avoiding emergency rooms because they are worried about possible coronavirus infection, according to a C.D.C. report.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. While hospitals in virus hot spots were often overwhelmed by the numbers of seriously ill Covid-19 patients, there were drastic declines in the volume of visits to emergency rooms across the country.

item.title: Trump Campaign Looks at Electoral Map and Doesn’t Like What It Sees
item.description: As polls show President Trump significantly trailing his rival, Joseph R. Biden Jr., his campaign is spending heavily in states, like Ohio, that it had hoped would not be competitive at all this year.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: President Trump is trailing his Democratic rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in every public poll of the election, but he has a large war chest and a solid political foundation on the right.

item.title: Drew Brees Apologizes for Calling Kneeling During the Anthem ‘Disrespectful’
item.description: Some of those who criticized Brees’s remarks were prominent professional sports figures, including members of his own team.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees last year. He was criticized by teammates and others this week for remarks about kneeling during the national anthem in protest of police brutality.

item.title: Genes May Leave Some People More Vulnerable to Severe Covid-19
item.description: Geneticists have turned up intriguing links between DNA and the disease. Patients with Type A blood, for example, seem to be at greater risk.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A transmission electron microscope image of a U.S. case of coronavirus.

item.title: With Steve King Gone, Does the Democrat Have a Shot in His Iowa District?
item.description: J.D. Scholten was preparing for a rematch with Mr. King, the controversial Iowa congressman. Then Mr. King lost the Republican primary.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: J.D. Scholten was only about 10,000 votes shy of defeating Representative Steve King in 2018.

item.title: Virginia Governor Plans to Order Robert E. Lee Statue Removed
item.description: A statue of the Confederate general in Richmond is controlled by the state, but the city’s mayor said he would propose a bill to remove additional Confederate monuments there.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: Protesters of the death of George Floyd chanted “Tear it down” on Tuesday as they gathered around a statue of Robert E. Lee, a Confederate general, in Richmond, Va.
